timeline.bodyText: Maybe it'd be helpful to sort the items in each block alphabetically? It kind of makes it easier to find a specific element.

timeline.bodyText: All these variables are used in several methods, so I think they would have to be class members anyway? What I'm getting at is that the comment about GC is possibly not necessary. I don't remember the exact details about the GC bug though, so I might be wrong!
timeline.author: JonLavi

replies.bodyText: @Rachael-E maybe we can get consensus on when to add the comment and when not, then I can add to the contrib guidelines.
replies.author: jenmerritt

replies.bodyText: @jenmerritt Good question! If the only reason that we are making the variable a class member is to protect against GC, then we need a comment here to explain why. If however the class variable is there because it is being used multiple times within the class across multiple methods, then the comment is not necessary.
replies.author: Rachael-E

replies.bodyText: Thanks! I've added a note to the contrib guide for consistency going forward.
replies.author: jenmerritt

timeline.bodyText: You can do this in the fxml file by adding disable="true". That parameter would apply to the elements when the app is started up, and will then be overwritten when the state changes (e.g. through the method calls)
timeline.author: JonLavi

timeline.bodyText: In previous samples we didn't chop longer lines because of URLs. So in theory we could write this on one line, but I'm not too fussed either way
timeline.author: JonLavi
JonLavi

replies.bodyText: Yes this came up in our session earlier this week - and basically exactly what you said! Either way is fine but we should be consistent and seems like the consensus is to call the async first then listener. I will make sure this is added to the contribution guidelines.
replies.author: jenmerritt

timeline.bodyText:
technically we're not hiding the progressIndicator if this error message is hit. Not that it matters, because if we got this far the samples is not very useful anyway 😛 .
If you wanted, you could put the line hiding the indicator (128) directly beneath line 123
(`featureLayer.addDoneLoadingListener(() -> {)

That way, the indicator disappears as soon as the layer is 'done' loading, regardless of which LoadStatus comes back.
This is being a bit pedantic though - maybe samples readability is better with the call on progressIndicator where it is right now
timeline.author: JonLavi

replies.bodyText: As discussed, progress indicator is hidden on the geodatabase failing to load but not for feature layer / table for readability.
replies.author: jenmerritt

timeline.bodyText:
Lets be a bit more specific with these variable names and call them nameTextField, etc.
I noticed these in the code below and it said name.getText(), which was a bit confusing without knowing what king of object name was.
timeline.author: JonLavi

timeline.bodyText:
I think it would be helpful to elaborate on this message to tell the user why their input is invalid (e.g.
The name cannot contain the following characters:  
. ; ' \
timeline.author: JonLavi

replies.bodyText:
Also wondering, can it contain other special characters? e.g. $%&*, etc?
Might be easier to just restrict the input to roman letters (Maybe there's a method for it, like .isWhitespace?).
replies.author: JonLavi

replies.bodyText: Other special characters are fine. I've amended the error message to be more explicit, definitely better for the user!
replies.author: jenmerritt

timeline.bodyText:
The is a very clear way of limiting the input, and the resulting message is also very helpful.
In case you were interested, there's also the option of adding a listener to the TextField, to stop users from typing in invalid characters alltogether:
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/15615890/recommended-way-to-restrict-input-in-javafx-textfield
I always find it a bit frustrating though when I try and type into a field and no characters appear, so much prefer the way you did it here (giving an error when trying to submit).
timeline.author: JonLavi

replies.bodyText: Thanks - will save that link. Agree I think it works in this case to validate after but might come in for a future sample 👍
replies.author: jenmerritt

timeline.bodyText: I think we could get away with removing the try/catch block here, and dealing with any exceptions within a try/catch block within the method updateFeature. This is because it looks like that is the source of any potential exception, so that would be the place to catch/throw them.
timeline.author: JonLavi

replies.bodyText: I've altered this so if you could double check the updateFeature method to make sure I've got the try/catch right.
replies.author: jenmerritt

timeline.bodyText:
If we wanted, we could pre-select one of the three options in this combo box, effectively eliminating the scenario where no Item is selected. Eg. after adding the enum values to the box:
accessComboBox.getSelectionModel().select(VersionAccess.PUBLIC);   

That way you could get rid of this block entirely.
However I do like the way it is right now, with the prompt 'select', as it doesn't imply any of these options are the 'standard'. So feel free to keep it as is! Just thought it'd be woth mentioning pre-selecting a value.
timeline.author: JonLavi

replies.bodyText: I like the select too, so will leave and see if it comes up again in the next review and get a consensus if needed.
replies.author: jenmerritt

timeline.author: JonLavi

replies.bodyText: Agreed, looks more readable with those spaces
replies.author: jenmerritt

timeline.author: JonLavi

timeline.bodyText:
I've noticed there are a lot of calls to serviceGeodatabase.getVersionName(). It looks as if this is the central place where a change to that value happens, meaning perhaps it might be nice to save it as a member variable (e.g. String currentGeodatabaseVersion), from which other methods could read, avoiding the repeated calls of the methos .getVersionName.
However there's an argument to be made about that approach creating two 'sources of truth', and in a more complex app the actual serviceGeodatabase and a string currentGeodatabaseVersion could go out of sync, creating a whole other bunch of problems...

  
    
      
        Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
                    currentVersionLabel.setText("Current version: " + serviceGeodatabase.getVersionName());
          
          
            
            		serviceGeodatabaseVersion
          
          
            
                    currentVersionLabel.setText("Current version: " + currentGeodatabaseVersion);
          
      
    
    
  

I'm not too attached to any solution, so I'll just leave this here as a comment rather than a request for a change 😛
timeline.author: JonLavi

replies.bodyText: Yeah this is a really good point. I had this discussion with myself and I had the fear of ending up with two sources of truth which is why I stuck with the 'gets'. I'll leave this comment open for second review too.
replies.author: jenmerritt

replies.bodyText: @Rachael-E
replies.author: jenmerritt

replies.bodyText: @jenmerritt I'm ok with this the way it is, with the calls to getVersionName. I think it's readable and helps understand the flow: at least for me!

timeline.bodyText:
I think this all looks alright. Other samples usually put a call to applyEdits in the .addDoneListener, but since we're just doing the 'apply' when versions are switched, this is ok.
Another thing I've noticed is that updateFeatureAsync only throws one type of exceptions:
IllegalArgumentException - if feature is null:
https://developers.arcgis.com/java/latest/api-reference/reference/com/esri/arcgisruntime/data/FeatureTable.html#updateFeatureAsync(com.esri.arcgisruntime.data.Feature)
So, perhaps if you include a null check before this method is called (line89?) we can get rid of the try/catch alltogether?
timeline.author: JonLavi

replies.bodyText: Ah nice. I've added into the existing if statement in that selection listener as seemed to make sense there.
replies.author: jenmerritt

timeline.bodyText: new line between initialize() and the try block needed here (just for readability)

timeline.bodyText: we can move this line of code up to just under the setOnMouseClicked call, and remove the repeated code on line 149. That way the reference to this Point2D is kept and both if statements can reference it without having to repeat the code.
timeline.author: Rachael-E
Rachael-E

timeline.bodyText: I'd be tempted to abstract this out into its own method (validateTextInput). This is quite a chunk of code for handling input which detracts from the main point of this method, which is to show the ServiceVersionParameters etc functionality. We don't often go for individual methods but in a case like this where there is a lot of UI specific case handling, it's ok to move that out.
timeline.author: Rachael-E
Rachael-E
Rachael-E

timeline.message: add link to docs in readme

timeline.bodyText: since we are using serviceGeodatabase across multiple methods, we can remove the comment for garbage collection here. Let's only use that comment if the sole purpose it has been made a class variable is to counteract garbage collection!
timeline.author: Rachael-E
Rachael-E

timeline.bodyText: the indentation is a little out on this line: there is an auto indent function in IntelliJ if you haven't come across this already which helps sort things like this!
